subject: Languages
title: How Languages Build and Destroy Complexity
description: A quick, practical guide to How Languages Build and Destroy Complexity.

hook.text: Some languages have incredibly complex grammar. Others are streamlined. Languages cycle between the two.

buildup.text: Latin had complex verb conjugations. French simplified them but added a mandatory subject pronoun instead.

discovery.text: When grammar simplifies in one area, complexity usually increases somewhere else to compensate.

twist.text: No language is objectively simpler overall. Simple morphology means complex syntax, and vice versa.

climax.text: Languages are constantly remodeling â€” tearing down old structures and building new ones from the rubble.

punchline.text: Grammar is a house that's always being renovated. Nothing is ever truly finished.

quiz.question: What happens when a language simplifies its grammar in one area?
options: Complexity usually increases in another area to compensate
